Second, we're talking here about whether
it's good for you to have been created and

65.text: Philosopher David Benatar says that being created is a harm; it's a bad thing, because

70.text: of what he calls "the Asymmetry between Pain and Pleasure." The absence of pain is good:

77.text: an empty room in which nobody is suffering - well that's a good thing. But the absence

81.text: of pleasure is only bad if there is someone who exists who is missing out. An empty room in which

92.text: who cares? Missing out on pleasure is only bad insofar

95.text:
as it produces actual pain. Nonexistence is
good from the point of view of potential people

102.text:
who would otherwise have suffered. But nobody
laments the nonexistence of all the

106.text: people who could be here experiencing pleasure with us.

108.text: This asymmetry between pain and pleasure, Benatar says, explains why we generally think it would be wrong to create

115.text:
someone if they're only going
to suffer, but at the same time we don't

118.text: feel like we're obliged to create new people so that they can experience pleasure.

123.text: That's because, Benatar says, from the point of view of nonexistence avoiding suffering is what matters.

The upshot is that if you create someone you
are responsible for all the pain they suffer,

148.text: life with only 1 second of pain, it's still better for them never to

153.text: have been created. They would have avoided the suffering, and since they wouldn't exist

175.text: So Benatar is an anti-natalist. Anti-natalism is the position that people should not have children, it's a

bad thing to do. You could be anti-natalist
for all kinds of reasons: environmental reasons,

198.text: He thinks that we actually have a moral duty to not have children. Which

203.text: means that nobody can have any reproductive rights. Remember my video on human rights? You can't have

210.text: a moral right to do something that you have a moral duty not to do. You could still adopt children

216.text: who are currently alive, and Benatar doesn't think this necessarily means we need to have forced sterilisation,

222.text: but obviously if this became a generally adopted viewpoint society would change hugely.

228.text: It might also have profound theological implications. If you're a believer

But if you're very clever you might have
spotted something odd about Benatar's argument.

244.text:
Feminist and applied ethical philosopher Christine
Overall challenges the Asymmetry of Pain and

250.text:
Pleasure. She asks, "Is it really good that
no-one is suffering from the point of view

257.text: of potential people?" Potential people don't exist: they have no point of view. To

265.text: be potentially existing is the same as not existing. If avoiding suffering is good

272.text: it must be good from the point of view of people who already exist. So when Benatar says that nonexistence

277.text:
is good from the point of view of potential
people who would otherwise have suffered,

281.text: it's a cheat: there is no such point of view. Potential people don't exist to have a point of view.

288.text:
If the question is "Are you worse off being
created?" then we need to ask "Worse off than

294.text:
what?" Words like 'Better' and 'worse' are
comparative: they require us to have

299.text: two states that we can compare but nonexistence is not a state that anyone can be in. In the scenario

307.text: in which you are not born, it can't be

309.text: the case that you would have been better off

311.text:
because you wouldn't have been
*anything*, never mind better off.

315.text: That doesn't mean though that having children is definitely an OK thing to do. In fact in her

321.text: book "Why Have Children?" Overall argues that it's actually a very serious moral decision

326.text: that we all need to be thinking more about. I really do recommend that book: we've talked about once

330.text: before on the channel when I did a video on father's rights and child support, and I still

335.text: get angry comments under that one.

337.text: Thinking philosophically about having children prompts us to remember just what a serious

341.text: decision it is; and how important all the rights and duties and responsibilities that come with it are. It also

348.text: prompts us to think more generally about what a good human life is - for everyone.
